sn1.34:0.2: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities
sn1.34:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
sn1.34:1.2: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the host of a hundred felicities, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
sn1.34:1.3: Standing to one side, one deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn1.34:2.1: “Among mankind there are no sensual pleasures that are permanent.
sn1.34:2.2: Here there are sensuous things, bound to which,
sn1.34:2.3: drunk on which, there’s no coming back.
sn1.34:2.4: That person doesn’t return from Death’s dominion.”
sn1.34:3.1: “Gloom is born of desire; suffering is born of desire;
sn1.34:3.2: when desire is removed, gloom is removed;
sn1.34:3.3: when gloom is removed, suffering is removed.”
sn1.34:4.1: “The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.
sn1.34:4.2: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
sn1.34:4.3: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,
sn1.34:4.4: but the attentive remove desire for them.
sn1.34:5.1: Give up anger, get rid of conceit,
sn1.34:5.2: and get past all the fetters.
sn1.34:5.3: Sufferings don’t torment the one who has nothing,
sn1.34:5.4: not clinging to name and form.
sn1.34:6.1: They gave up judgement without falling into conceit;
sn1.34:6.2: craving for name and form was cut off right here.
sn1.34:6.3: They cut the ties, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope.
sn1.34:6.4: Though gods and humans search for them
sn1.34:6.5: in this life or the next, they never find them,
sn1.34:6.6: not in heaven nor in any abode.”
sn1.34:7.1: “If neither gods nor humans see one freed in this way,”
sn1.34:7.4: are those who revere that supreme man,
sn1.34:7.5: who lives for the good of mankind, <j>also worthy of praise?”
sn1.34:8.1: “The mendicants who revere one freed in this way,”
sn1.34:8.4: Having understood the teaching <j>and given up doubt,
